column4: i have a Two part question: 1)how do i get my Places menu to show the "File system" option again? 2)how do i get nautilus to give me an option to manipulate a file as root? like the sudo command, but without having to know the terminal commands for everything i want to do
you can do alt-F2 and run  ' gksudo nautilus'
did you see my answer?
you can make a launcher with that command if you wish - butbe very careful - running the file manager as root is a great way to wreck your system :)
yes i like it, i think i'll use it
just heed the warning :)
i plan to be careful, it's just annoying how some things block me out when all i want to do is make a copy of the file
don't use nautilus as root on any files in your home directory - they will suddenly belong to root and be inaccessible to your user
in case i do, how do i make them usable by me again?
change the ownership back to your user
for instance make them owned by user:user (group as well)
is it gonna change the WHOLE home directory? or just whetever files i mess with?
the ones you mess with
but *don't* use it in your home directory
or /tmp for example
i should need to but i'll keep it in mind, thanks for teh warning
in general it's better not to use a graphical file manager as root. Learning some commands is better really
just wondeirng: does gksudo allow me to run ANY GUI as root?
yes it should
but don't :)
oh that's powerful
running apps as root is a *bad* idea
yeah i'm just using it for future reference
